awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: The Interplay Between Convex Feasibility Problems and Minimization Problems in Signal Recovery
awd_abstract_narration:
Signal recovery encompasses the large body of inverse problems in which a signal is to be restored or reconstructed from the observation of data consisting of measurements physically or mathematically related to it. The importance of this field stems from its pervasiveness in numerous areas of science and engineering, including medical imaging, geophysics, astronomy, electron microscopy, nondestructive testing, seismology, telecommunications, social media analysis, and homeland security. This project investigates foundational principles guiding the formulation of signal recovery problems as convex optimization problems and develops new strategies and methodologies for data processing that significantly improve the efficiency of existing techniques and broadens their scope.

This research focuses on the interplay between two prominent frameworks that coexist in relative independence in signal recovery, namely convex feasibility problems and convex minimization problems. These two approaches employ different principles to exploit the prior knowledge and the data, their mathematical formalizations lead to distinct fixed point paradigms, and the algorithms used to solve them do not rely on the same techniques. The investigator shows that, despite these profound divergences, fruitful connections can be established between the two formalisms, that are mutually beneficial and suggest new models and algorithms. An important outcome of this research is a relaxation model that bridges the gap between feasibility and minimization formulations. Another highlight is a novel proximal geometric framework for solving structured minimization problems using a deep cutting plane technology adapted from convex feasibility algorithms. The impact of the theoretical findings and of the new algorithms resulting from this research is illustrated through applications to concrete signal recovery problems.

por.por_cntn:
Signal recovery is the problem of recovering the original form of a signal or an image from the observation of other signals mathematically or physically related to it. The importance of this field stems from its pervasiveness in numerous areas of science, engineering, medicine, and homeland security. This project investigates foundational principles guiding the mathematical formulation of signal recovery problems, with a special emphasis on the interplay between feasibility problems and optimization problems. In feasibility formulations, one seeks to find a signal consistent with the available prior information and the observations modeled as hard constraints; in optimization formulations on seeks to construct a cost function that aggregates prior knowledge and observations, and that penalizes the deviation from ideal solutions. We have established several connections between these two types of problems that have deepened our understating of models and created methods able to tackle new applications. In particular, we have shown that most minimization formulations are relaxations of feasibility formulations. This research has also impacted the area of nonlinear signal processing by proposing a novel fixed point formalism to handle nonlinear observation models efficiently, including the case of inconsistent observations. Additionally, our research has impacted the modeling of neural networks, one of the main tools supporting artificial intelligence and modern data analysis. There, we have shown that one of the main devices used in solving optimization problems, namely the proximity operator, also models most activation steps in a neural network structure. This has led to advances in the understanding of neural networks and the quantification of their robustness. Finally, we have developed a new generation of block-iterative splitting algorithms to efficiently solve very large scale problems arising in signal processing and data science.
